awd_titl_txt: Engaging Youth in Expanded STEM Career Pathways through Clean Energy Literacy Development
awd_abstract_narration:
The University of California, Berkeley, Lawrence Hall of Science plans a five-year project to investigate the capacity of a previously developed clean energy-focused intervention model to affect positive learning outcomes and greater career awareness among a broader audience of under-represented group students aged 14-16. Students (approximately 975) at 12 school sites located in East San Francisco Bay Area urban communities with large underrepresented group populations will participate in opportunities to learn and apply STEM content and information and communication technology (ICT) skills in the context of investigating energy and its usage. These opportunities will be presented in school day courses and in after school programs. Project participants will: learn clean energy-related and NGSS-aligned content; conduct research on related topics that generates scientifically accurate information valuable to local communities; and make links between particular content areas and a range of career pathway options. Students also will also make public information sessions aimed at increasing community awareness of clean/green energy related topics. This proposal builds on a prior project by studying the capacity of the intervention to affect student career and academic choices and determining what modifications will support effective broad-scale implementation.   

The project will investigate the impact of its activities on participant development of functional identity (i.e., the disposition, skills and knowledge necessary for effectively pursuing and maintaining STEM-related educational and career-related trajectories in the future). It will address several key research questions: (1) How successful the intervention model is in fostering NGSS mastery, in impacting how students value the application of science, in affecting course taking choices, and career interest with a group currently not in the traditional STEM pipeline; (2) How the experience of the intervention model differs for participants who are recruited through different strategies, i.e. self-selected vs. assigned; and (3) Does the project have an effect at the school level related to student preparation and career trajectory as a result of the implementation of the model. Successful implementation of the project will result in an effective, scalable intervention model that can be used in a variety of settings for the purpose of preparing youth to participate in clean energy/STEM related careers.

por.por_cntn:
Engaging Youth in Expanded STEM Career Pathways through Clean Energy Literacy Development was a seven-year project to engage 14-16 year old youth (Grades 9 -10) residing in urban communities in an array of learning activities designed to increase clean energy-related science, technology, engineering and mathematics (STEM) content understanding and awareness of associated career pathways. In implementing the project, a programming model was developed for presentation in both in-school out-of-school settings. This programming was specifically designed to provide participants a combination of relevant content learning and related community science research activities that enable them to connect science learning experiences with relevant community issues. In this regard, programming featured activities that provide opportunities for youth to perform small-group, collaborative, extended investigations that address relevant issues, generate useful information, engage their curiosity, enable them to exercise greater control of their learning, and motivate further science learning. Throughout its implementation, project programming was presented by trained staff members in both in-school and out-of-school contexts as either an enhancement component of ongoing courses or as a stand-alone set of experiences.

Intellectual Merit

 To gain an understanding of the its impact on youth participants, the project included a  research component that focused on investigating the degree to which its programming model impacted participants’ STEM content mastery, valuing of science, course taking choices, and career interest. Over the course of the project’s implementation, 700 youth who attended a variety of East San Francisco Bay Area high schools participated in its activities. At each school site, pre-and post- surveys were administered to gather data about students’ attitudes towards and interests in science and STEM careers. In addition, group interviews were conducted with select student participants to gather more in-depth information regarding content learning and to also gather formative feedback about the program experience. Furthermore, project team members made observations of program activities to gain insight into the implementation of programs with a focus on understanding similarities and differences between in-school and afterschool programs.

Broader Impacts

Findings generated through implementation of the project indicate that engagement in its programming resulted in positive learning experiences that challenged previous notions of and ways of relating to science. Participation in the project increased how youth value science, but more so when implemented in the in-school setting than the afterschool setting. It appears that youth perceptions of whether project programming was “science” differed across settings. That is, in the school setting, the curriculum was different from the regular science experience and changed the perception of science from a school subject to a subject that had meaning in their own lives and in the world. On the other hand, in the afterschool setting, where students were comparing their experience to other afterschool offerings (e.g. playing sports, making t-shirts) the experience was considered as “just more school.” That is, the value individuals associated with the experience seemed to be relative to what they considered as the alternative options for activity during the same time.

In terms of future design of STEM education programming, project findings indicate that connecting science learning experiences to the lived experiences of youth and real-world issues is key to fostering greater STEM engagement, increasing perception of science as a valuable tool for addressing pressing environmental and public health matters, and the catalyzing the development of  “science minded” and environmentally conscious individuals. Regarding STEM education policy, findings suggest that it is important to integrate community-based research experiences in school-based science learning, as such an approach represents a potential framework for connecting and supporting teachers, schools, districts and communities.
